Ioannides added that 2,600 emergency services workers have been specially trained to work during the Olympics, but he did not clarify what additional preparations were needed. A meeting is planned for Thursday to discuss possible strike plans or other actions. I'll probably watch the DNC Convention, and I'm looking for something to talk about. With the explosion of blogs on the Internet I'm looking forward to reading what the People's opinions are rather than the mainstream talking heads' scripted responses. I think the main point of the DNC convention will be to raise the level of political discourse. Here are five questions I want to have asked at the Convention: 1) Where is the Democratic Party headed? This is not something easily presented on commercial media, because the 'he said, she said' style of partisanized reporting obscures intra-party discussions that are not acrimonious. Nevertheless, this is a critical question that we need to address, and are starting to talk about. 2) What is the role of the executive branch in our political system? It's hard to remember a time of legislative importance relative to the executive branch. Nevertheless, the apogee of the imperial Presidency is the political convention, with a centralized media apparatus focusing entirely on the national election of one man. It's time we examined this structure. 3) How can the Democratic Party work to build channels for effective political communication? What are the obstacles to such channels? There will not be another chance to ask this question with 15,000 media personalities in one room. The 'establishment' will all be in attendance - it's time to meet them, learn about them, and figure out how to reconcile the two parallel worlds. 4) What is the role of bipartisanship in politics? Is political polarization a bad thing, and if it is, what can the Democrats do about it other than abject surrender? The most endangered species in politics is the political moderate, both on the left and the right. What does this mean? If the coming battle is truly epic, what happens to the losing side? Will Kerry be impeached if he doesn't take Congress as well as the Presidency? Now is the time to ponder political extremism, and what the appropriate response might be. Dare I say socialism? 5) Where is the Democratic party on intellectual property rights? This is the political issue that concerns the craft of blogging itself - fair use, regulation of the internet, and copyright. Whether you are at the Convention, watching it on TV or not, please consider making suggestions for what we should be talking about. Now is not the time to be complacent and passive. Much is at stake; civil liberties, gay marriage rights, a declining labor movement, a weakening of environment laws and regulations, outsourcing of high-paying jobs to lower-paid workers overseas, NAFTA, the list could go on. This is our time to consider the Democratic Party and what it means to oppose Bush's right-wing stranglehold on the issues I just mentioned. Let's use the time during the DNC convention well because time is running out on our freedoms. Doug Smiley

Thanks to John for urlLink pointing out this imortant date in labor history. July 5 is also an important date; it marks the 70th anniversary of Bloody Thursday, the most dramatic day of the San Francisco General Strike. This strike gave birth to the International Longshore and Warehouse Union (ILWU), which broke from the mobbed-up International Longshoremens' Association (ILA) that is still the dominant union on the East Coast. The general strike was a watershed moment in labor history that gave birth to much else besides, including -- so I am told -- SEIU Local 250, the country's first healthcare workers' union, and a local which today probably has at least twice the membership of the entire ILWU. What the ILWU lacks in size, though, they can make up for in potential power -- the ability to shut down the ports is no small power. They have often done it not only for their own betterment but for higher political purposes: from the boycotts against imperial Japan and apartheid South Africa to the political strikes against the imprisonment of Mumia Abu-Jamal, the WTO, and the war in Iraq, the ILWU has not only bargained but unilaterally imposed conditions and lent strength to prominent political struggles. For this, they have always faced repression, from the time the government tried to revoke the citizenship of ILWU president Harry Bridges and have him deported (he was an Australian immigrant, and they said he had falsified his citizenship application when he said he was not a member of the Communist Party; this may have been true, and I have seen it said that Bridges was not only a Party member but a member of the Central Committee -- but I haven't paid much attention to the details, and quite frankly, who cares if he was?) to the first use of a Taft-Hartley injunction not against a strike but in the case of a lockout, under the current George Bush. So everyone should give a shout-out to the ILWU and to the continuing American Revolution, beginning with a rededication to our task at hand for this November.

urlLink New York Fire, Police Unions Say Talks At Impasse Strike During GOP Convention Possible POSTED: 12:08 pm EDT August 10, 2004 UPDATED: 8:30 am EDT August 11, 2004 NEW YORK -- Police and firefighters announced an impasse Tuesday in their contract negotiations with the Bloomberg administration, refusing to rule out a strike or sickouts during the Republican National Convention. "Everyone has a limit, and the mayor needs to know we're close to our limit," said Stephen Cassidy, president of the Uniformed Firefighters Association, at a press conference at City Hall. For the last two weeks or so, off-duty police officers have been showing up at Mayor Michael Bloomberg's daily public appearances and picketing outside Madison Square Garden, the site of the Republican National Convention beginning Aug. 30. Several other city unions, such as District Council 37, the city's largest, have already accepted a 5 percent raise plus $1,000 over three years with 2 percent coming from productivity enhancements such as lower pay and benefits for new hires. A mayor's spokesman said Tuesday that the city's last offer to the police and fire unions was a $1,000 lump sum payment plus an 8 percent pay hike -- though 5 percent of the raise would come from productivity enhancements. The police and firefighter unions said they had no intention of accepting productivity enhancements, which they denounced as "givebacks." Police have been without a contract since July 31, 2002, and firefighters since May 31, 2002. The situation fits a pattern of retroactive contracts and negotiations that routinely ignore expiration dates and end in arbitration. But Tuesday, the police and fire union representatives said they deserve more significant raises than other city employees. The police union declared an impasse in its negotiations with the city several weeks ago, while the firefighters said they reached the same conclusion this week. "Mike Bloomberg says we're no different than people that push paper," said Cassidy. "That's a joke. It's a disgrace. It's an insult to the firefighters and police officers who risk their lives every day." Bloomberg has said the city cannot afford to give significant raises to municipal unions. "Using the DC 37 framework which has been used to reach agreements with 140,000 city employees, we have offered both unions raises of up to 8 percent with a $1,000 lump sum but about half would be funded by productivity enhancements, which both unions have balked at," said Bloomberg spokesman Ed Skyler. "In the meantime, it doesn't matter what tactics they use, the mayor isn't going to be intimidated into making a bad deal for the city." Leaders of the police and fire unions also said they would not guarantee that they would not strike -- even though such a move is barred by law. "We must keep in mind that the frustration level is high and we cannot count anything out in our struggle," said Patrick Lynch, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.
